title: Alex Williams (footballer, born 1983)
text:
Alexander Boyd Williams (born 15 January 1983), is a Scottish <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="forward%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a>. He has previously played in the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20First%20Division">Scottish Football League First Division</a> for several clubs.
Career.
Williams began his career with <a href="Stirling%20Albion%20F.C.">Stirling Albion</a>, where he exploded onto the scene as a teenager, scoring 21 times in 61 appearances, and being linked to moves with big English clubs, such as <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Spurs</a> and <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20F.C.">Charlton</a>.
Williams headed to <a href="Greenock%20Morton%20F.C.">Greenock Morton</a> in 2002 for £50,000. His time at Morton, and his subsequent career prospects, were marred by an unproven betting scandal after the club lost a 14-point lead at the top of the <a href="Scottish%20Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a> to finish the season in fourth position. Williams later claimed that this rumour had a severe effect on his career, as clubs were unwilling to consider signing him despite his track record.
After a short loan spell with <a href="Queen%20of%20the%20South%20F.C.">Queen of the South</a>, Williams joined <a href="Clyde%20F.C.">Clyde</a> in 2005. He made an instant impact, scoring after three minutes of his début against <a href="Brechin%20City%20F.C.">Brechin City</a> in the <a href="Scottish%20Challenge%20Cup">Scottish Challenge Cup</a>. Williams finished as Clyde's top scorer <a href="Clyde%20F.C.%20season%202005-06">that season</a>, scoring 13 league goals, and played in a famous <a href="Scottish%20Cup">Scottish Cup</a> victory over <a href="Celtic%20F.C.">Celtic</a>.
Williams moved to Australia in 2006, and joined <a href="Armadale%20SC">Armadale</a>. This only lasted a few weeks, and he later returned to Scotland to join <a href="Ross%20County%20F.C.">Ross County</a>. He only played a handful of games for County, as injury disrupted his time there. Williams then joined up with old team Clyde in January 2007, when he was re-signed after playing as a trialist in a series of matches. His contract with Clyde expired in May 2007. It was not renewed, and he subsequently left the club.
He joined <a href="Ayr%20United%20F.C.">Ayr United</a> in July 2007 and proved a hit with the Somerset Park faithful, scoring plenty goals for the club, including two tremendous strikes away to <a href="Raith%20Rovers%20F.C.">Raith Rovers</a> in the <a href="2007-08%20in%20Scottish%20football">2007–08</a> season. In the <a href="2008-09%20Scottish%20Cup">2008-09 Scottish Cup</a>, he scored a last minute equalising goal against <a href="Ayrshire%20derby">Ayrshire derby</a> rivals <a href="Kilmarnock%20F.C.">Kilmarnock</a> to earn a replay and a much needed cash boost for the club.
On 8 June 2009, his contract with Ayr was terminated by mutual consent, and he subsequently signed for <a href="Dundalk%20F.C.">Dundalk</a> in the <a href="League%20of%20Ireland">League of Ireland</a>, where he scored on his début. Williams signed for <a href="St%20Patrick%27s%20Athletic%20F.C.">St. Patrick's Athletic</a> in January 2010. Williams scored on his St.Pat's debut vs <a href="Wexford%20Youths%20F.C.">Wexford Youths</a> in a pre-season friendly, the "Saints" won 3-0. In late June 2010, his club contract was terminated by mutual consent, and on 22 July he joined Stenhousemuir on a one-year deal. He was released at the end of the <a href="2010-11%20in%20Scottish%20football">2010-11</a> season along with 11 others.
In January 2013, Williams and Kristopher O'Malley pleaded guilty to charges of supplying designer drugs <a href="methylone">methylone</a> and <a href="naphyrone">naphyrone</a>. The lawyer representing Williams said that he had become involved in this activity because of financial difficulties suffered due to a gambling addiction. Williams was jailed for 32 months.
Williams joined <a href="Scottish%20Junior%20Football%20Association">Junior</a> side <a href="Luncarty%20F.C.">Luncarty</a> in 2013.
